-------------------------------1242488124

Thanks Jim, I will give audacity a try too, I have a few of these type  
programs on my pc, but never knew how to use them nor for what, maybe each one  
has a special area, I can always wait til my daughter comes back to MI she  
graduated college, and is looking for work as US Marshal, or Boarder 
Patrol,  FBI, something at state level I guess, MI is limited but, I need her back 
 here,   She went to a Radio/TV broadcast school after getting out of  high 
school, I would bet she would know all about how to work those  programs.  
This lastest recording, the minute one, I could heard them  conversing away, 
sounded like a regular lecture, wish I could understand them  better. sf
 
 
In a message dated 5/16/2009 10:12:36 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time,  
clockdryve@... writes:

 
 


Hi, give the AUDACITY software another try. Has option to slow the  
recording down. Another nice feature is that you can use either a highpass or  
lowpass filter (sometimes that is all that is needed) and changing the PITCH  is 
a very handy tool. Always KEEP an original copy of your recordings. I just  
save a copy from inside audacity (to desktop or somewhere) then I will star
t  my work on trying to clear it up. Save the original (and proceeding 
enhanced  version(s) by using the "file" button at to left corner oif program. 
There you  would SAVE "selection" as MP3.(To upload to here) or save to WAV 
(is bigger)  but higher qulity. Can always convert the wav to mp3 from withing 
audacity  also. *you will need to get the mps "pluging" from the website, 
and follow the  information to install it "manually" (once is only needed) 
that way you get  the mp3 converter program free. But really...Audacity is a 
pretty good program  to have round. Has a nice "undo" fesature too, if you 
make a mistake. Happy  Hunting ;) Jim H --- In _EVP-ITC@yahoogroupsEVP-_ 
(mailto:EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com) ,  SnowfireL@..,  Sn

adjust

to

be

my 
> questions,  now I got to figure out a way to make them clearer, and maybe 
slow em

> > sure that it is a  voice. I does have a cadence similar to someone 
> speaking,

bu
> > could just as easily be something present in the  environment-<WBR>a na 
> it is

probably

> > 
> > For an EVP to  be considered proof positive of spirit communication by 
> the 
>  > community at large, it has to be clear enough that many people hear 
the  
> > same thing, without hints or coaxing. If you have to have high  quality 
> devices 
> > to make it out, it just isn't good  enough. That does not mean it isn't 
a 
> > true EVP, just that it  isn't good enough to stand as evidence.
> > 
> > As for the  whistle, it sounded like feedback to me as well, but I will

>  electronics 
> > or EMF's that could contribute to feedback. Even so,  if I am trying to 
> > remain unbiased and objective, there is no way  for me to say this is a 
> spirit, 
> > without personally  being with you when you caught it. The only thing I 
> can 
> >  still say about it is could be, but for me it is non conclusive.
> >  
> > If someone does not hear what you are hearing, try to remain  objective 
> and 
> > just understand that it isn't personal.  You have to understand that 
with 
> > just these recordings alone,  there is no way to scientifically prove 
> what 
> > you have  recorded is spirit communication. If you could get 
consistent, 
> >  intelligent question and answer recordings, then you would be alot 
>  closer.
> > 
> > Here again, we are back to the "So what?"  thing. You don't HAVE to 
prove 
> > anything scientifically, unless  you want others to completely believe 
in 
> > your evidence.
>  > 
> > The theory that is being kicked around is that some EVP's  are 
personal, 
> > and only meant for the person recording them to  hear. If this is the 
> case, no 
> > matter how clear  something is to you, others may not hear it.
> > 
> >  April
